is not anything tremendously new which

docker to their credit again put

its really been a game changer and we're
going to talk a little bit more about
how that's evolved so I first started
working with docker back in
2014 at the OpenStack
conference down at Atlanta and that was
all the buzz on the show floor is that
gee you know this startups done this
quick pivot and they've you know created
this compelling new technology and we
got interested right away because we
really saw the potential that we also

and so they've made a commitment back
then too be radically open and we've
been working with them along with a

that led to Solomon at docker con
mid-2015 making this announcement about
the open container initiative it's a
working group of the Linux Foundation
and the key tenants of this effort have
been that it's not going to be tightly
controlled by any single vendors so one
of the things that we always look at is
this idea of how do you balance the

governance and that's really what the
oci is all about as it relates to the
base container technology
so a lot of people have been involved

really want to give a shout out to the

they also saw this desire to really

that really helped spur this dialogue

oci is a really interesting project
because it's actually its primary output
is specs the runtime spec and the image
format spec and as you can see from the

open source reference implementation
that's part of run c as well as by
industry industry products you can see
the cartoon docker hamster wheel running
as well as core OS rocket as well as a
whole ecosystem of vendors products and
users
so the open oci certification program is
a project that a number of members of
oci are working on to try to provide an
oci certified runtime and an oci
certified image and the groups have
defined those as meeting all of the
muster required provisions from the
specs so it's not about you have to use

opens you can use the open source
